title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
1. Motivating example


Research question: “To what extent do different teaching methods influence students’ ability to produce high-quality written texts?”
Method: Randomization and a CJ experiment, specifically:




Researchers randomly assign students to two different teaching method
Students write one or more texts
Researchers collect students’ written texts
Researchers randomly assign judges to compare pairs of students’ written texts
Judges produce a dichotomous outcome, reflecting the relative quality of each text




Estimand: “On average, is there a difference in the ability to produce high-quality written texts between the two groups of students?”
Estimator: the BTL model
Estimates: estimated BTL scores, or their transformations



Following current CJ practices

Thus, it is intuitive to think that:

The outcome’s ability to reflect the “true” differences between texts largely depends on the validity of the model’s assumptions [1].



Circle the assumptions of General form:

correlation (one per pair)

Circle the assumptions of Case V:

Equal discriminal dispersion
Zero correlation

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
3.1 Case V and statistical analysis
But, are Case V assumptions violated?


Thurstone: equal dispersion may not be applicable when researchers assess complex traits or heterogeneous stimuli
\(\longrightarrow\) Evidence of this can be found in misfit statistics?
Zero correlation is almost certainly invalid in two scenarios:
\(\longrightarrow\) when intricate aspects of stimuli cause judges’ biases, ultimately introducing dependencies between stimuli.
\(\longrightarrow\) when an additional hierarchical structure is relevant to the stimuli.



Equal dispersion:

“misfits” texts are texts with more judgment discrepancies than others [2–5]
“misfit” judges are judges who deviate substantially from the shared consensus.

Zero correlation:

additional relevant characteristics, exert an uneven influence on judges’ perceptions, creating biases. Since the discriminal difference of the stimuli becomes an observable outcome only through the judges’ perceptions, these biases introduce dependencies between the stimuli.
the shared context created by additional hierarchical structures introduce dependencies between stimuli (clustering) Not properly handled

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
3.1 Case V and statistical analysis
But, what are the problems with this?


Different dispersions, neglecting judges’ biases and hierarchical structures
\(\longrightarrow\) reduce precision of parameter estimates
\(\longrightarrow\) overestimation of trait’s reliability
\(\longrightarrow\) drawing spurious conclusions [6]
Discarding ‘misfit’ observations [2–5]
\(\longrightarrow\) discard valuable information
\(\longrightarrow\) introduce bias into trait estimates [6, 7]
\(\longrightarrow\) drawing spurious conclusions [6]




discarding ‘misfit’ observations is a conventional practice in CJ

3.2 Measurement and hypothesis tests
Researchers use the BTL model as a measurement model for CJ [3–5, 8–12], i.e., they use the estimated BTL scores, or their transformations, to conduct additional analyses or hypothesis tests, for example:



Identify ‘misfit’ judges and stimuli [3–5]
Detect biases in judges’ ratings [3, 13]
Calculate correlations with other assessment methods [5, 12],
Test hypotheses related to the underlying trait of interest [12, 14–19]

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
3.2 Measurement and hypothesis tests
But, what are the problems with this?


Ignoring uncertainty of BTL scores
\(\longrightarrow\) introduce bias + reduce the precision of hypothesis tests [20, 21]
\(\longrightarrow\) diminish statistical power of tests
\(\longrightarrow\) increase likelihood of type-I or type-II errors [6], i.e., drawing spurious conclusions.




We need a more systematic and integrated framework that enhances statistical accuracy while strengthening measurement reliability and validity.

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
4.1 The conceptual-population model
Assuming that we can access to:



all repeated judgments
made by every available judge
for each pair of texts
produced by each pair of students




Then:



\(n_{I}\) represents the number of students
\(n_{A}\) denotes the number of texts available per students
\(n_{J}\) indicates the total number of judges, and
\(n_{K}\) represents the number of judgments each judge performs
\({n_{I} \cdot n_{A} \choose 2} = \frac{ (n_{I} \cdot n_{A})! }{ 2! (n_{I} \cdot n_{A} - 2)! }\) represents the total number of comparisons
\(n = {n_{I} \cdot n_{A} \choose 2} \cdot n_{J} \cdot n_{K}\) denotes the total number of observation in the data

4.1 The conceptual-population model





\[
\begin{aligned}
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & := f_{O}(D_{RPUV}) \\
  D_{RPUV} & := f_{D}(T_{IA}, B_{JK}) \\
  T_{IA} & := f_{T}(T_{I}, X_{IA}, e_{IA}) \\
  T_{I} & := f_{T}(X_{I}, e_{I}) \\
  B_{JK} & := f_{B}(B_{J}, Z_{JK}, e_{JK}) \\

  e_{IA} & \:\bot\:\{ e_{I}, e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\

  e_{JK} & \:\bot\:e_{J}
\end{aligned}
\]

5. Abandoning the BTL model





\[
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & = O^{sc}_{RPUV} \odot C \\
  O^{sc}_{RPUV} & = O^{cp}_{RPUV} \odot S_{RPUV} \\
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & \sim \text{Bernoulli} \left[ \text{inv_logit}( D_{RPUV} ) \right] \\
  D_{RPUV} & = \left( T_{IA}[R_{1},P_{1}] - T_{IA}[R_{2},P_{2}] \right) + B_{JK}[U,V] \\
  T_{IA} & = T_{I} + \beta_{XA} X_{IA} + e_{IA} \\
  T_{I} & = \beta_{XI} X_{I} + e_{I} \\
  B_{JK} & = B_{J} + \beta_{ZK} Z_{JK} + e_{JK} \\
  B_{J} & = \beta_{ZJ} Z_{J} + e_{J} \\
  e_{IA} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{IA}) \\  
  e_{I} & \sim \text{Normal}(0,1) \\
  e_{JK} & \sim \text{Normal}(0, p_{JK}) \\
  e_{J} & \sim \text{Normal}(0,1)
\end{aligned}
\]


\[
\begin{aligned}
  O_{RPUV} & := f_{C}(O^{sc}_{RPUV}, C) \\
  O^{sc}_{RPUV} & := f_{S}(O^{cp}_{RPUV}, S_{RPUV}) \\
  O^{cp}_{RPUV} & := f_{O}(D_{RPUV}) \\
  D_{RPUV} & := f_{D}(T_{IA}, B_{JK}) \\
  T_{IA} & := f_{T}(T_{I}, X_{A}, e_{IA}) \\
  T_{I} & := f_{T}(X_{I}, e_{I}) \\
  B_{JK} & := f_{B}(B_{J}, Z_{K}, e_{JK}) \\
  B_{J} & := f_{B}(Z_{J}, e_{J}) \\
  e_{IA} & \:\bot\:\{ e_{I}, e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{I} & \:\bot\:\{ e_{JK}, e_{J} \} \\
  e_{JK} & \:\bot\:e_{J}
\end{aligned}
\]
